Just a little clarity for the calamity...the users of these drones might be violating FAA Regulations - but that is not criminal.  It is only a regulation.  Only Congress can inact laws.  Also, if the drones are not registered - which is still not a criminal offense - then the serial number is largely useless.   Also, some commercial and military drones do have a 6' wingspan.  No idea what or why the drone activity - but flying multiple large drones in close proximity, at night, even with IR or a flight management system requires several skilled drone pilots with more technology than the average recreational drone operator.  However, the same flight management software could auto-fly the drones in grid patterns as described - but that type of flying, for multiple devices is not you average hobbyist.  This could be as simple as commercial or military testing new equipment - or commercial operators performing LiDAR surveying - or (of concern) a rogue group learning to fly and operate in unison.  Sheriffs should take this serious.  A drone with a 6' wingspan could carry more than a camera.  Also, this is noticeably close to DIA. Let's review - 6' Wingspan, Operating At Night,  Flying in Formation, Observed over a large geographic area, reportedly low level and presumably in or near controlled airspace - 
Nothing in there screams private citizen and certainly not a single private citizen. So Commercial or Government are the only possible logical answers. Government, out in that region could be Bureau of Land Management doing use surveys, EPA looking for violations, who knows. Without a doubt some bureaucrat in any government agency that is fascinated with drones could be let loose to dream up multi-million dollar Fed Grants so they can create their own "air force". Commercial ventures are not so likely since they would have to get flight permission and be very transparent with FAA and other regulators. Plus NO corporate lawyer would green-light night flights like that; the liability would be staggering. And night flying would be fairly worthless to things like mapping and surveys. Somebody in Government likely knows... they just don't feel the need to enlighten the unwashed masses.

"William Merideth in July said he saw a drone flying above his property in Hillview, Kentucky.
He believed it was spying on his 16-year-old daughter who was sunbathing in the garden. So he took out his shotgun and blasted the drone out of the sky. He was arrested for wanton endangerment and criminal mischief.
Now a Kentucky court has declared Merideth an innocent man. Bullitt County District Court Judge Rebecca Ward on Monday dismissed all charges against Merideth, reported local TV station WDRB-TV."

I’m a UAV pilot and have my own drone biz and I know that a 6 foot drone, if that’s accurate, is very rare. These are not stoners or just some people having fun. My smallest, littlest drone, all in, was around $3000. Drones of this size are almost always used for either agriculture or delivery. There’s several start up drone firms that use these sized drones for medical delivery or Amazon as well. Amazon has been hiring pilots for delivery testing for a while now, unfortunately they don’t pay jack. Intel has a drone this size, I think it’s called a Falcon, that several of these startups use, but most of these start ups are not going to last, this is most likely Amazon. Unfortunately this is also where I think the next terrorist attacks are going to come from, drones! Pretty easy to drop bombs from or drop chemical or biological weapons from; can you imagine a fleet of them?? This is bad and it’s coming!
